content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Find the GitHub Skill section and how many courses are under the 'First day on GitHub' heading.  Please interact with https://github.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find the GitHub Skill section and the 'First day on GitHub' courses, I should look for learning or resources-related sections. The "Resources" button [6] in the top navigation is a logical choice to explore further content related to GitHub skills, tutorials, or learning paths.
Action: Click [6]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.1
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The "Learning Pathways" option [12] under the "Explore" section is most likely to contain the GitHub Skill section and information about introductory courses such as "First day on GitHub." I should click it to find the relevant details.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I am now on the "GitHub Learning Pathways" page, which should have details about the GitHub Skill section and the "First day on GitHub" courses. The main content might be lower on the page, as the current visible section is just an introduction.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The section now says "Pick your pathway," and I can see some pathway cards, but the bottom part of the screen is hidden by a cookie consent banner that might obscure other relevant pathways or links related to 'First day on GitHub.' To get a clearer view of the rest of the options, I should accept the cookies.
Action: Click [11]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The cookie banner is gone, and I can see the first row of pathway options such as "AI-powered development with GitHub Copilot" and others. To find the "GitHub Skill" section or the "First day on GitHub" heading, I need to scroll further down and look for beginner-level courses or an introductory pathway.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The pathways shown so far are specialized or advanced, such as Copilot, automation, security, and administration. There is nothing yet related to "First day on GitHub" or a clear "GitHub Skill" section, so I need to scroll further down to find beginner or foundational content.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached a section with user testimonials and quotes, but there is still no sign of the "First day on GitHub" or "GitHub Skill" section. It is possible that the sought section is further down the page.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: This section still contains testimonials and company logos, with no sign of the "First day on GitHub" heading or the "GitHub Skill" section. I need to continue scrolling to look for the required sections further down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have now reached the "GitHub Learning Pathways" section, which is likely the GitHub Skill section needed for the task. The introduction describes self-paced tutorials designed for progressing from beginner to expert, but there is still no visible list or heading for "First day on GitHub" or the number of courses under it. I need to scroll down further to locate that specific heading and count the courses.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I see an introduction to the learning pathways but still no "First day on GitHub" heading or list of specific courses. It is likely further down below this prominent introductory section, so continuing to scroll is needed.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.65
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the footer of the page, and I have not found the "First day on GitHub" heading or a list of courses under it. It appears that the desired section is either hidden deeper (perhaps under the "Start your learning pathway" button) or was missed in a previous scroll. The button [8] is prominently placed and might lead to a detailed list of available courses and pathways, potentially including the "First day on GitHub."
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screenshot shows the "Pick your pathway" section with several advanced pathways listed (Copilot, Actions, Security, Enterprise), but there is still no sign of the "First day on GitHub" heading or beginner content. I should scroll further down, as beginner pathways typically appear after the featured advanced ones.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The section currently visible only lists advanced learning pathways with "Explore your [topic] learning pathway" links, and still no sign of the "First day on GitHub" heading or beginner content. The "Featuring expert insights from:" header suggests that the next section may be unrelated testimonials or endorsements, but I need to confirm if anything relevant lies further below.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The visible section is full of testimonials and client quotes, not course or skill content. Still, there is no "First day on GitHub" heading or related beginner courses in sight. Additional scrolling is needed to check if these appear further down.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.82
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current section still contains only testimonials and now company logos. There is still no sign of the "First day on GitHub" heading or the GitHub Skill section. The content is not related to pathways or courses, so further scrolling is required.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.85
Completion: 0.84
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I have reached the "GitHub Learning Pathways" section, which matches the "GitHub Skill section" referred to in the task. There is an introduction to self-paced tutorials, but I do not yet see the "First day on GitHub" heading or the listing of courses. I need to scroll further to find that specific content and count the courses.
Action: Scroll WINDOW; down
Confidence: 0.96
Completion: 0.87
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The screen shows a section on optimizing GitHub use and a button labeled "Start your learning pathway." This button likely leads to a detailed list of available courses, which may include the "First day on GitHub" heading. Clicking the button is the next step to view the course content.
Action: Click [8]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.9
